lines.text: You know, Ann, I... I've always done a lot of dreaming. And lately it seems when I dream, your face gets mixed up in it.
Does it really, Abe? Tell me about them, Lincoln.
Well, I... I feel as though I'm going to be seeing your face 'til the day I die. Course, I know that that'll be pretty hard on you to have to look at my face that long.
Everybody to their own opinion.
Hmm?
Well, I... I think it's the dearest, kindest, most beautiful face in the whole world.
Oh, Ann, Ann. Course, I know that's just flattery, but I love it.
[death scene]
I know the truth, dear. It's goodbye.
No, no, Ann, dear. You're not going to leave me. I won't let you!
We must be brave, dear...
[looking up to the heavens]
Don't take me away. Don't take me away! It's so dark and lonesome!
Ann, you mustn't let go.
If they'd sing, I wouldn't be so afraid.
[a chorus of "Sweet By and By" swells up in the background]
We will meet there, dear.
Abraham Lincoln! Will you never learn to keep your feet in shoes?
I've hung my hat and here it stays till they knock it off with a bayonet. From now on, Mary, I'm going to run this war!
[an aide suggests that General Lee surrender]

[Grasping sword]
Surrender? My poor army! Why I'd rather die a thousand deaths than to do that to them.
There, there, General. You must lie down and rest.

[Introspectively]
Rest... that's a beautiful word.
There he is! Ugliest, laziest, smartest man in New Salem. Ain't ya, Abe?
Well, I don't mind my face; I'm behind it. It's the people in front that get jarred.
You taught me how to love.
Have I taught you to like it?
[both laugh]
You know, I feel like little Jimmy Watkins. He got a hunk of gingerbread the other day and said, 'I guess there's nobody loves gingerbread like I does and gets so little of it.'
Oh, Abe.
Ann, will you... will you marry me? I mean, of course, when I get out of debt and can support you?
Well, you know, Abe, I've intended to for a long while. That is, of course, if you ask me.
You... you mean...?
Yes, Abe... you've got your gingerbread.
Shucks, he'll never amount to nothin', no how!

[after Lincoln has beat Armstrong and others]
He said he was a peaceful man. He's been as peaceful as a wildcat.

[to Ann]
Well, my old daddy taught me how to work, but he never taught me how to like it.
Miss Todd, you thought my face was funny, and the way I dressed was funnier, but the joke's on you.
Why? I don't understand.
Wait'll yuh dance with me.

[to a dying Ann]
I gotta feelin' I'll be seein' your face till the day I die.

[to Mary]
You need a lotta patience to put up with me, Mary, but if anyone can do it, I'm sure you're the one.
Oh, by the way, Mrs. Lincoln, have you met General Grant?

[Laconically]
Ah met'em. Took us a week to get the smoke out of the curtains.

[Referring to Reconstruction]
We're going to take them back as if they've never been away.
